Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support participation of speakers and junior researchers in the 2014 Midwest Representation Theory Conference, to be held September 5-7, 2014 at the University of Chicago. Representation theory developed as a generalization of classical harmonic analysis, through which functions can be decomposed into their elementary components, much as a prism breaks light into its spectrum. The theory found wide applications in physical sciences (such as quantum mechanics) and in other areas of mathematics (notably number theory and geometry). The power of the theory comes, in part, from its utilization of algebra and topology in concert with analysis. This (almost) annual conference has been a source of important information for experts in the field, and many collaborative efforts have originated from discussions at these meetings.

This, the 40th anniversary of the original Midwest Conference, will honor the contributions of Rebecca A. Herb, and it will also be in memory of the Midwest Representation Theory Conference founder, Paul J. Sally, Jr. (1933-2013). The invited speakers will all be leaders in the field and will reflect recent developments in representation theory. We expect speakers will report on recent progress, including applications to number theory and geometry, and the state of the Langlands Program. Topics covered may include unitary representations of reductive Lie groups, Plancherel formula, admissible representations of p-adic groups, Galois representations, functorial transfer to general linear groups, Theta-correspondences, orbital integrals, and Fourier transforms. The conference webpage is located at the following address: http://www.math.lsa.umich.edu/MRTC_2014/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 40th anniversary edition of the Midwest Representation Theory Conference was held at the University of Chicago September 5-7, 2014.  The conference was organized by S. DeBacker (Michigan), D. Goldberg (Purdue), and S. Weinberger (Chicago). The conference carried out its plan of both honoring the 65th birthday of Rebecca A. Herb and serving as a memorial to Paul J. Sally, Jr., the founder of the Midwest conference and originally a co-organizer of this event.  Since the first Midwest Representation Theory Conference was held in 1974, this area of mathematics has seen tremendous progress, progress which owes much to the mentoring prowess of Rebecca Herb and Paul Sally, Jr.  In the tradition of the two honorees, the conference provided graduate students (25) and junior mathematicians (10) with enthusiastic support for and encouragement of their research endeavors.  The conference also provided attendees and others with the opportunity to see firsthand the importance of excellent mentorship.  

All the speakers were, in some way, connected with Herb or Sally.  There were 10 speakers over the course of three days: J. Adams (Maryland), J. Arthur (Toronto), A. Moy (HKUST), B. Speh (Cornell), L. Spice (TCU), M. Tadic (Zagreb), M.F. Vigneras  (Jussieu), D. Vogan (MIT), and J. Wolf (Berkely). Their lectures addressed a broad range of topics in representation theory of real and p-adic groups, and included applications to other areas of research, including number theory, algebraic geometry, and harmonic analysis.   Several speakers have made the slides of their lectures available at the conference webpage http://www.math.lsa.umich.edu/MRTC_2014/.  

The 2014 Midwest Representation Theory Conference hosted 65 participants, including the speakers. Of these, 25 were graduate students, 10 were junior researchers (defined as those with completed Ph.D., but yet to gain tenure) and 30 were senior researchers. There were 14 female participants (4 graduate students and 10 senior researchers). Nine of the 65 participants were from foreign institutions (Canada, Croatia, France, Hong Kong, and India).   The diverse population had plenty of opportunities for collaboration as well as time for informal discussions about current research as well as research avenues to pursue.
